Award.AwardTitle: RET Site: Science and Mechatronics Aided Research for Teachers (SMART)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a 3 year continuing award to support a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering Site program at the Polytechnic University of New York entitled, "RET Site: Science and Mechatronics Aided Research for Teachers", under the direction of Dr. Vikram Kapila.

This Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering Site will provide a professional development opportunity to 10 high school teachers per year (total of 30 teachers) in the areas of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). These teachers will work with and be mentored by Dr. Kapila and three senior personnel as they conduct inquiry-based, hands-on, engineering research in the exciting field of mechatronics during six-week long summer workshops.

The project will benefit the teachers by reinforcing their science and math skills; enriching their STEM experience through exposure to real world engineering research; developing and honing their research, communication and presentation skills; and providing them opportunities to network with STEM educators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: 30 teachers received training, research experience, and mentoring in the multidisciplinary field of mechatronics. Each year, six-week long summer workshops were conducted in a collaborative environment consisting of 11 researchers and five engineering faculty. To advance discovery and learning, project team employed hands-on structured projects and prototype product development activities. A 35-item survey assessed teachers’ familiarity with mechatronics skills, concepts, and devices introduced during the training. Teachers’ self-perception with project topics improved from 1.83/4 average (pre) to 3.18/4 average (post). On pre- and post-project technical quizzes, teachers’ average was: 57.8% (pre) and 66.2% (post); yielding 14.5% improvement. Project teachers have made significant contributions to research on biomechanical fish locomotion, biomimetic sound-localization, damage detection in beams, a temperature-control instrument for creep test, etc. For example, under Dr. Kapila’s guidance, Mr. Fisher and Ms. Geraldi’10 and Mr. Bernhardt, Ms. Mallar, and Mr. Outerbridge’11 worked with a graduate and an undergraduate student to develop a series of iPhone controlled robotics projects. To obtain qualitative feedback on project effectiveness, an external evaluator conducted the following activities: interviews of research supervisors, site visit to interview teachers and conduct observations in labs, and follow-up interviews with selected teachers. The following are samples drawn from evaluation reports: “I now have first-hand experience of what it means to ‘do’ as well as to learn science,” and “The best professional development program.”

 

Broader Impact: Among the 30 participants were 8 women and 9 teachers from underrepresented groups. Project broadened the training of over 35 engineering students by engaging them as lab assistants. In 2011, one participant was selected as one of 20 Siemens STAR teachers nationwide. Project activities were widely disseminated through technical publications and media outreach. Our RET Site project was one of only 16 NSF-funded research and education projects selected and invited by NSF to showcase its Mobile Apps for Robotics interactive exhibit at the 2nd U.S. National Science and Engineering Expo, Washington, DC, April 27-29, 2012. Project teachers’ success stories include raising funds, creating lab experiments, and developing curricula to integrate mechatronics activities in teaching and learning. Two illustrative examples of teacher success stories follow.

Mr. Bernhardt has created an 8 week section on iPhone/Arduino development. Students wired a model home with an Arduino, Wi-Fly, lights, and a servo (acting as a garage door opener). They then worked on developing an iPhone App to open and close the garage door and turn lights on and off. His Game Programming course now develops games for iPhone and Androids in addition to web-based games. The Lynbrook School District also approved a full year Robotics course, which includes both Lego and Tetrix robots to be programmed in RobotC.

Mr. Ryan Cain engaged 99 second graders from five classes in a culminating project on “River Erosion Model” to conclude a second grade unit on Earth materials. A Makerbot 3D printer was utilized to fabricate scaled-models of residential and commercial buildings that were installed on a river bank, modeled on a table-top using a variety of clay and sand.
